Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multi-Beam SEM/FIB for Multidisciplinary Materials Study and Training

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The multi-beam scanning electron microscope (SEM) coupled with a focused ion beam (FIB) has the capability to cut materials and to provide nano-scale images with very high resolution. Acquisition of this instrumentation will enable fundamental multidisciplinary research at Jackson State University (JSU) by researchers from civil engineering, electrical engineering, chemistry, biology, material science, and physics. Key research activities include efforts to advance knowledge on 1/ new microbial technologies to strengthen soils to reduce damage from earthquakes 2/novel approaches to treat the multi-drug-resistant bacteria Salmonella with magnetic nanoparticles and 3/ enhanced fuel cell development, which reduces pollution. The instrumentation will become a key element of JSU's research infrastructure. The SEM/FIB will be used in undergraduate and graduate courses and will promote partnerships and collaborative activities with surrounding universities and national engineering research centers.

This advanced SEM/FIB instrumentation has a milling depth up to 100nm, with image resolutions of 2.5 nm. This capability will allow geotechnical engineering researchers to determine the 3D micro- and nano-scale structure of bio-mediated soil materials, enabling discovery of microbial induced calcite precipitation not visible from the surface. Researchers will monitor the change in micro-structural features of stratified silt-sand-gravel mixtures after dynamic triaxial tests, improving understanding of the liquefaction behavior of stratified contractive soil composites. The SEM/FIB will be used to characterize the interfacial bonding between geopolymer composites and reinforcing steel coated with enamel under extreme environmental conditions. The SEM/FIB will allow chemistry researchers to characterize the 3D structure of bacteria and the interaction between bacteria and nanoparticles with hybrid graphene oxide for label-free biosensing. Researchers in biology will use the equipment to study the health effects of engineered nanomaterials. Physicists, electrical engineers, and material scientists will use the SEM/FIB to study the 3D internal morphology and related mass/charge transport behavior of fuel cell components to develop a new generation of fuel cell.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The scope of work of this project included (1) to obtain a multi-beam scanning electron microscope (SEM) coupled with focused ion beam (FIB) for multidisciplinary materials study and training and (2) to use the SEM/FIB to serve multi-disciplinary research groups at Jackson State University (JSU) and institutions around in the analysis of three-dimensional (3D) structures and compositions of samples tackled in the research. The scope of work has been completed successfully and no further action is anticipated on the grant.

Through a rigorous searching and bidding process, a highly efficient SEM/FIB manufactured by TESCAN, Inc. was acquired and successfully installed in the SEM Laboratory at JSU. The SEM/FIB has been effectively used to characterize samples for nine research groups at JSU, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Engineer Research and Development Center (ERDC), and University of Mississippi Medical Center (UMMC). The capacity of this instrument makes it possible to visualize 3D structures of the material samples and determine the compositions in the meantime. The 3D images and compositions from the SEM/FIB helped the researchers understand the morphology, microstructure, physicochemical change of the samples. Twenty peer-reviewed journal papers containing sample characterization results from the use of SEM/FIB have been published by the research groups at JSU. Sixteen relevant presentations at regional, national, and international conferences were made. Three faculty members, two technicians, two postdoctoral researchers and five graduate students have been trained in the use of the SEM/FIB instrument. More than ten faculty members, three postdoctoral researchers, twenty graduate students, and twelve undergraduate students have been involved in research activities that used SEM/FIB for sample characterization.

The sample characterization results from SEM/FIB have been disseminated to scientific communities through publications in professional journals and presentations at regional, national and international conferences. These publications and presentations have strong impacts on the knowledge and knowhow of the contemporary sciences and technologies such as nanomaterials. The SEM/FIB acquired through this grant significantly enhanced the sample analytical and imaging capability of JSU and made all the publications possible. This SEM/FIB obtained through this grant will continue to play an important role in characterization and imaging of samples in the research activities at JSU and research institutions in and around Mississippi.
